thread.title: Mariners enjoy first unbeaten campaign in short school history
thread.title_full: Mariners enjoy first unbeaten campaign in short school history

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Mark Haskell)
title: Mariners enjoy first unbeaten campaign in short school history
text:
Mariners enjoy first unbeaten campaign in short school history Oceanside to compete in KVAC Class B title game Oct. 21 in Newcastle By Mark Haskell | Oct 20, 2015 
Thomaston — Undefeated seasons are nothing new to longtime high school girls varsity soccer coach Darryl Townsend. 
But the same cannot be said for his players from Oceanside, which recently wrapped up just such a campaign on the heels of a 5-0 victory over visiting Belfast on Monday, Oct. 19 at Wasgatt Field. 
The Mariners earned their first unbeaten regular season in the five-year history of the girls soccer program as they finished 12-0-2 on the fall year, with ties against Waterville and Mount View of Thorndike as the lone blemishes. 
Townsend coached the Georges Valley girls 17 years before becoming the Oceanside coach in 2011 when GVHS merged with Rockland District High School to form Oceanside High School. 
Townsend's teams made unbeaten seasons and Mountain Valley Conference championship games in Class C a nearly annual occurrence, with the Buccaneers' last unbeaten season in 2009 — when the team won its last state crown, a 1-0 win over Orono. 
Now, the Mariners hope to, as the Buccaneers did that year, catch lighting in a bottle and run the playoff gamut, this time in Class B North. 
Townsend said prior to the start of this season he would be “elated” with a 10-4 record. But another unbeaten season? 
“Of course I think any time you don't lose any games you've got to be happy about it,” said Townsend. “Is it unexpected? Absolutely, it was a surprise. But that's just more of a credit to the kids and their work ethic, I think, honestly. They work extremely hard, like a lot of teams do, but they've been overachieving on an everyday basis. We play good defense and we try to keep teams off the scoreboard best we can.” 
In the team's 5-0 win Oct. 19 at Wasgatt Field, the Mariners were led on offense by Makenna Brooks (2 goals, assist), Casey Pine (goal), Abby Veilleux (goal), Kelsey Brooks (goal, assist), Bri Dugan (assist) and Lily McVetty (assist). 
Oceanside held a 20-2 edge in shots, 11-0 advantage in corner kicks and 2-1 edge in direct kicks. 
Kalyn Grover made two saves in goal for the Mariners, while Cori Shooter made 17 saves in net for the Lions. 
Townsend said one of the keys for his teams is “putting up as many goose eggs for the other team as you can” and the Mariners have done just that this season. 
Oceanside has outscored opponents 39-3 — an average of 2.78 goals per game — with 12 shutouts. 
Townsend conceded it has not been easy as they “don't blow a lot of teams out” and by the same token, “win a lot of close games.” 
“I hope that's going to prepare us for the heavy competition we're going to see come playoff time,” he said.” 
The Mariners conceded a goal in an 8-1 win at Belfast Sept. 8 and battled host Waterville to a 2-2 double-overtime tie Oct. 1. 
The Mariners have outscored opponents 20-0 at home this season and held foes scoreless for six straight games early in the campaign, and ended the year having not conceded a goal for five straight matches. 
And Oceanside, as the region's top seed, will have home field throughout the Class B North playoffs. 
“I tell the girls, 'Just get out there and find a way,' ” the veteran coach said. “Find a way to get it done. And they do. They've got just enough talent and desire to get the job done.” 
The Mariners also have a chance for revenge, of sorts, on Wednesday, Oct. 21 when they will face Waterville for the Kennebec Valley Athletic Conference Class B championship at Lincoln Academy in Newcastle. The game kicks off at 7 p.m. 
Townsend said he's “not too hung up on that game tomorrow” against Waterville as he plans to keep his players rested and loose. 
“I just want to get out of there safely and look forward to next Tuesday [for our first regional quarterfinal playoff game],” he said. 
The Mariners lost one of its best defenders, Becca Boggs, to a torn anterior cruciate ligament midseason, while defenders Lauren Hatch and Emma Lee also have been banged up the past week. 
Townsend said that Haylee Witham and Meredith Mitchell have “done a fine job” playing for Hatch and Lee as the defense has not missed a beat. The veteran coach added he has used talented veteran forward Makenna Brooks sparingly the past few weeks in an effort to keep her rested for the postseason. 
Offensively, the Mariners rely on Makenna Brooks, cousin to identical twin sisters Kelsey and Jillian Brooks, all of whom have pumped in multiple goals this season. Casey Pine also has been an offensive threat, as has freshman Hope Butler, who scored both goals in the team's 2-2 tie with Waterville earlier this season. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class B North, Oceanside (12-0-2, 176.9133 points) is first in the 18-team region. The top 12 teams qualify for the playoffs.
